put.description:
Update a Consumer Profile --- **NOTE** The object on the server will be updated as such, reflecting a complete override. PUT should never be used to do a partial update. Use PATCH instead. Please check the specific patch/put example in the request and response sections. --- Only existing consumer profiles can be updated with this method. This method can't be used for creating resources. Use the related POST for the creation of consumer profiles.

GET/consumerProfiles/{azureADB2CObjectID}FAILEDconsumer-profiles-system-api001002001000000URI_TOO_LONGERRORPAYLOADThe server refuses to service a request because the target of the request is too long for the server to interpret.https://api.ece.com/faq

Get Consumer Profile Coupons

ATTENTION:

This method is returning all ever-activated coupons for the related consumer profile.

There is no filtering, e.g., based on a valid from and valid until range happening.

Furthermore, equal coupon UIDs (couponUID) can be returned for multiple times and are not summarized into one. By doing this, it is feasible to identify the usage of the same coupon, e.g., for a free coffee on different days/times.

The control of the overall maximum usage of a coupon will be solved outside of Salesforce Sales Cloud, e.g., with Azure APIM and Typo 3.

AzureADB2CObjectID.description:
Azure AD B2C Object ID One of the Azure AD B2C discovery results is, that the frontend components (portals, mobile apps) have to know and have to use the Azure AD B2C Object ID for the communication with Azure AD B2C.

Furthermore, Salesforce is using also the Azure AD B2C Object ID as primary key (external reference).

BirthDate.description:
Birthdate of the User

Consent.description:
Consent Item

A consent (item) unique identifiers are the combination of all contained attributes (consentTypeCode, consentTriggerCode, consentChannelCode, consentDate, consentText, version).

For that reason, multiple consents can existing for, e.g., the same consentTypeCode (_'communication'_), consentTriggerCode (_'raffle'_), consentChannelCode (_'Email'_).

```json
{
  ...,
  "consents": [
    {
      "consentTypeCode": "communication",
      "consentSourceCode": "webapp",
      "consentTriggerCode": "raffle",
      "consentChannelCode": "Email",
      "consentDate": "2022-12-20T01:05:00Z",
      "consentText": "TBD",
      "version": "1.0.0"
    },
    {
      "consentTypeCode": "communication",
      "consentSourceCode": "iOS",
      "consentTriggerCode": "raffle",
      "consentChannelCode": "Email",
      "consentDate": "2023-04-09T12:48:33Z",
      "consentText": "TBD",
      "version": "1.1.2"
    },
    ...
  ]
  ,...
}
````

ConsentChannelCode.description:
Describes how the consent is given.

  | Value | Description |
  | --- | --- |
  | Email | Consent is given via Email OptIn |
  | Web | Consent is given via frontend interface, like a checkbox |
  | App | Consent is given via Mobile App |

ConsentDate.description:
Date on which the consent was given

Best practice for providing timestamp information is the following UTC notation (ISO 8601: https://www.iso.org/iso-8601-date-and-time-format.html):

The API currently is expecting the following format:

YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ssZ          2022-11-23T16:58:59Z
YYYY-MM-DDTHH:mm:ss.SSSZ      2022-11-23T16:58:59.123Z

ConsentSourceCode.description:
Describes source (system) used for consent confirmation.

  | Value | Description |
  | --- | --- |
  | webapp | ECE Web Portal |
  | iOS | ECE iOS mobile app |
  | android | ECE Android mobile app |

ConsentText.description: A description, why a consent text (instead of the consent version) is necessary (from business perspective), will be provided by Jan Vogel (2023-01-25).

ConsentTriggerCode.description:
Consent Trigger

Describes the circumstance, which was decisive for the fact that a consent was necessary. Can be extended in the future.

| Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| raffle | A raffle has been held. |
| consumer-profile-registration | Consumer Profile registration |
| coupon-activation | Coupon activation |
| newsletter-subscription | Newsletter subscription |
| profile-preferences | Consumer Profile consent change(s) in preferences |

ConsentTypeCode.description:
Consent Type

| Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| communication | Consumer consents to receive (email) communication  |
| privacy-notice | Text of the consented privacy notice given by the consumer |
| AGB | Terms and conditions |
| loyalty | Loyalty |
| third-party-tracking | Third party tracking |

The consent (and the contained consent items) are ECE center indepenent.

MetaMessage.description: Optional list of messages providing information about the process of the request.

MetaMessageCode.description: Unique technical or business code of the message, that you can use to adapt your application behavior or display a translated human readable message.

MetaMessageDetail.description:
Optional in-depth human-readable description of the message.

It has to be used only by development team to help troubleshooting, and never to display information to end users.

MetaMessageDomain.description: The name of the service, class or other identifier for where the error occurred to better provide an understanding of what the issue was.

MetaMessageExtendedHelp.description: A URL that the developer can use to learn more about the issue.

MetaMessageLevelCode.description:
Level of severity of a message.

| Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| INFO | Level is used to provide diagnostics information concerning the process of the request. |
| WARN | Level is used to inform that the process of the request has been partially done, because it didn't respect all the business rules, or a part of the request has not be successfully processes. |
| ERROR | Level is used to inform that the process of the request met a blocking internal error or business rule, cancelling the request process. |

MetaMessageLocation.description: The location of the error. The location type first generally restricts the origin.

MetaMessageLocationTypeCode.description:
Location type

Determines how the client should interpret the location property.

| Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| PAYLOAD | Payload |
| QUERY_PARAMETER | Query Parameter |
| HEADER_PARAMETER | Header Parameter |
| PATH_PARAMETER | Path Parameter |
| REQUEST | Request |

MetaMessageReason.description:
Optional text to provide human readable information concerning the message.

It has to be used only by development team to help troubleshooting, and never to display information to end users.

MetaMessageReference.description: Optional information providing context information about the origin of the message. For example, a complex request body provides the object reference associated with the raised error code.

MetaMessages.description: This is a list of messages providing information about the process of the request.

MetaStatusCode.description:
Define the available statuses when returning a response.

| Value | Description |
| --- | --- |
| SUCCEEDED | Is used when the request has been well processed. It goes along with an HTTP status of 20X. |
| PARTIALLY_SUCCEEDED | Is used when the request has been only partially processed for technical or functional reasons (in case of backend unavailability, timeout, or unrespected business rule, for instance). It goes along with an HTTP status 2xx. and at least one warning message explaining why the request has not been fully processed.   |
| FAILED | Is used when the request has not been successfully processed. If it is for functional reasons, it goes along with an HTTP status 4xx; if it is for a technical reason, it goes along with an HTTP status 5xx. |

XForwardedForHeaderParameter.name: X-Forwarded-For
XForwardedForHeaderParameter.description:
**Forwarded For** for providing the client IP adresse(s).

This includes intermediate system hops, like proxies.

The X-Forwarded-For (XFF) request header is to provide the original IP address of a client connecting to a web server/API through a proxy server.

In a typical scenario, when a client connects directly to a server, the server can easily identify and log the client's IP address. However, when a client connection passes through one or more proxy servers before reaching the final server, the server only sees the IP address of the last proxy server in the chain. This can be problematic, especially if the final proxy is a load balancer or part of the same installation as the server, because it doesn't provide useful information about the actual client.

To address this limitation, the X-Forwarded-For request header is used. Proxies along the connection route append the client's IP address to the X-Forwarded-For header, creating a chain of IP addresses. The leftmost IP address in the chain represents the client's original IP address, while the subsequent addresses correspond to the intermediate proxies.

By examining the X-Forwarded-For header, the web server can extract the original client IP address and use it for various purposes, such as logging, security measures, geolocation, or personalization. This header has become a de facto standard for identifying the originating IP address when clients connect through proxy servers, enhancing the server's understanding of its clients' true location and behavior.

**Warning: Improper use of this header can be a security risk.**

# Syntax

Elements are comma-separated, with optional whitespace surrounding the commas.

```
X-Forwarded-For: <client>, <proxy1>, <proxy2>
```

# Security and privacy concerns

The X-Forwarded-For header exposes privacy-sensitive information, like the client's IP address, and therefore, user privacy must be considered when implementing this header. The header's reliability depends on the presence of trusted reverse proxies between the client and server.

If all proxies and the client are trustworthy, the list of IP addresses in the header can be trusted. However, if there is a risk of malicious or misconfigured clients or proxies, the header may have been spoofed or tampered with.

When trusted reverse proxies are present, the final IP addresses in the X-Forwarded-For header (added by the trusted proxies) can be considered trustworthy, but this assumes the server is only accessible through those proxies and not directly.

If the X-Forwarded-For header is used for security-related purposes like rate limiting or IP-based access control, only IP addresses added by trusted proxies should be used. Utilizing untrustworthy values can lead to security vulnerabilities, such as bypassing access control or causing resource exhaustion.

On the other hand, untrusted values from the leftmost part of the header should only be used when there will be no negative impact from potentially using spoofed values.

In conclusion, deploying the X-Forwarded-For header requires careful consideration of user privacy, the presence of trusted proxies, and the appropriate handling of the header's values to ensure security and prevent negative consequences.

---

410GoneConsumerProfilesCreateCustomRespo.description:
`Gone`

***The HTTP 410 status code indicates that a resource is no longer available on the server and that this condition is likely to be permanent.***

***It is meant to assist with web maintenance by telling the recipient that the resource is intentionally unavailable and that its links should be removed.***

***This status is used for limited-time services and resources associated with individuals no longer connected to the server's site.***

***The server owner decides how long the mark remains.***

***An existing consumer profile with same Azure AD B2C Object ID is marked for deletion. The duration for which the resource will remain unavailable is decided by the server owner. The deletion process needs to be finished first, before the creation of a new consumer profile (same Azure AD B2C Object ID) can be created.***

---

413PayloadTooLargeDefaultResponse.description:
`Payload Too Large`

***The 413 status code indicates that the server refuses to process a request because the request payload is too large for the server to handle.***

***The server may close the connection to stop the client from continuing the request.***

***If the situation is temporary, the server should provide a Retry-After header to indicate when the client may try again.***

414URITooLongDefaultResponse.description:
`URI Too Long`

***The server is refusing to service a request because the target of the request is too long for the server to interpret.***

***This occurs in rare cases, such as a client converting a POST request to a GET request with a long query, when the client is caught in a redirection loop, or when the server is being attacked.***

200CustomResponseConsumerProfilesCoupons.description:
ATTENTION:

This method is returning all ever-activated coupons for the related consumer profile.

There is no filtering, e.g., based on a valid from and valid until range happening.

Furthermore, equal coupon UIDs (couponUID) can be returned for multiple times and are not summarized into one. By doing this, it is feasible to identify the usage of the same coupon, e.g., for a free coffee on different days/times.

The control of the overall maximum usage of a coupon will be solved outside of Salesforce Sales Cloud, e.g., with Azure APIM and Typo 3.
